welcome: Hi, I’m Sebastian, a Product Designer at Zemoga. My passion is to help companies create amazing digital products to connect with their users.

paragraphs.title: Hi! I’m Sebastian.
paragraphs.text:
I am a Visual Artist from Bogotá, Colombia, currently working in the digital innovation industry.

Over the years working at Zemoga & MDS I’ve had clients from all over the world, which include Verizon, Walmart, PlayStation and Discovery, among others.

Im highly skilled at Research, Analysis, Visual Design, User Interface Design and Interaction Design, all of which I enhance with digital Illustration and motion graphics. My passion is to help companies create amazing digital products to connect with their users.

Over the past 8 years I've been building digital experiences and collaborating with awesome people. If you want to know more about me, my projects or simply grab a cup of coffee, just send me an email. I would love to hear from you.

My most recent job has led me to lead the internal design processes related to design system, service blueprint, documentation and Visual QA for the Great Wolf Lodge team. Besides that, I have been helping Verizon with their new product Family Money, a task that has been utterly satisfying and challenging at the same time.

Having led and being part of design teams for years in this young, rapidly growing technology environment - taught me how to balance business goals and engineering constraints as I unrelentingly advocated for the user.

I graduated from Pontificia Universidad Javeriana, Colombia with a degree in Visual Arts. This has taught me all the design spectrum, from analog and digital illustration, to typography, photography, sculpture, cinema and user experience, my specialized field for 7 years now.

I grew up in Colombia but have lived in different countries throughout my life - England, Argentina, Mexico. Having experienced different cultures has strengthen my ability to adjust to new challenges and embrace different cultures understanding all points of view and that is something you can see in my designs and also in my concept art.

cases.collaborators: Alex Martinez (Lead UX/UI) Alejandra Restrepo (Lead UX/UI)
cases.overview: Walmart is an American multinational retail corporation that operates a chain of hypermarkets, discount department stores, and grocery stores, it is considered the biggest retailer in the world. Their digital team is based in San Bruno, California, and we, as a team had to work closely with their design, business and marketing team.
cases.name: Walmart
cases.slogan: One of the biggest retailers in the world unifying two services into one.

home.alt: One of the biggest retailers in the world unifying two services into one.

features.title: Unify two apps into one
features.description: Major problems were two outdated apps both in forms and looks, logic structural problems in lots of the flows, and a design system without clear directions.

features.title: Deep users understanding
features.description: From screen UI convertion into new Breakpoints, to a complete facelift for the design system, including components, behaviours and interaction design.

features.title: Strengthened experience
features.description: An improved, clearer experience, with more tools for users, resulted in a solid and unified product that improves people's lives day after day in all their purchases.

sections.title: Problem Statement
sections.content:
After some years of walmart being in the digital and e-commerce arena, the product needed a redesign at every level since their two main services were offered apart from each other in two different apps. The main challenge was to unify the two experiences into One-app.

Some of those changes included redesigning the interface with key changes in site logic, UX explorations and ideations with a deep undestanding of the user flows, identifying pain points and opportunities to contribute and improve the overall experience.

In order to start improving the experience I was in charge of 4 main tasks:

  • - Convert over 500 screens to three requiered Breakpoints in order to start the complete facelift of the app and the website, using the new library components.
  • - Iterate over differen solutions for the filtering feature.
  • - Explore, analize and propose different solutions for the indoor mapping service, including interaction design, zoom states and UI.
  • - Propose new interactions for the hallway swap.

sections.title: Understanding the user
sections.content:
In order to tackle the problem, we had to understand what the actions of Walmart users were and their motivations. Originally, users had gotten used to separating purchases within apps in a way that seemed logical: Grouping consumables, perishable foods and groceries, and on the other hand, tools, services and appliances, among other things.

Years passed and motivations and needs varied. At this point, users needed not only a change in the type of service they obtained from digital products, but a frictionless experience that allowed having a single centralized purchase in a single app, in a single experience.

sections.title: Business requierements and Paint points
sections.content:
By the time I entered the project, Walmart’s main app had been downloaded 103+ million times since January 2014 across both iOS and Android. In 2020, it’s the No. 2 app in the iOS App Store’s Shopping section. Walmart Grocery, meanwhile, has seen more than 16 million downloads across iOS and Android during that same time period. It’s also ranked further down (No. 30) in the Shopping section on the App Store.

What this meant was a disparity of interest in the different Walmart services that were condensed into two applications. This made no sense as it does not represent the way people shop, which is not a binary experience.

Of course this meant that at the business level, grocery revenue was not being the same as Walmart.com, and the experience was feeling outdated in many of its parts, and this had to be solved quickly.

sections.title: Especific challenges
sections.content: The first big task consisted in the conversion of more than 500 screens to 3 required Breakpoints for responsive web and for Native in IOS and Android. When making these conversions, we began to evaluate all the flows that both apps had, to try to refine them. To be able to do this a joint effort of many months was needed, an understanding of the current and new design system, and a very clear and constant communication with all the agents involved in product development at Walmart and on our side.

features.title: Support Family Money app
features.description: Challenge consisted in designing a website that motivates, informs and encourages downloading the app, also letting the user access key information about the service.

features.title: Setting the foundations
features.description: Roadmap of different versions of the website, new interactive features and constant business and user findings were part of setting the pillars for the site.

features.title: Wide vision of the product
features.description: A clear, wide vision of key info, related articles and every advantage the product offers is portrayed on the website, resulting in a huge number of downloads for the product.

cases.name: Great Wolf Lodge
cases.slogan: Helping the largest family of indoor water park resorts in North America improve their booking process through calendars.

home.alt: Helping the largest family of indoor water park resorts in North America improve their booking process through calendars.

features.title: Clarify Deals and Booking process
features.description: Confusion with the deals, incomplete and misleading information and overall dissatisfaction were just some of the problems users had with booking.

features.title: Finding solutions
features.description: Constant iterations, multiple hypotheses and constant discussions with lots of user testing were necessary to build a new experience for for the booking flow.

features.title: Improved experience
features.description: With the new interaction design for the booking journey, clarity, coherence and a considerable impact on the company's revenue were achieved.

cases.name: IQOS
cases.slogan: Lead capturing platform to help introduce IQOS new products.

home.alt: Lead capturing platform to help introduce IQOS new products.

features.title: Lead capturing
features.description: The challenge consisted in creating a platform to capture new leads for the brand introducing its values, benefits and a new service called IQOS Coach.

features.title: Funnel users to take action
features.description: In order to generate engagement on the platform, it was necessary to highlight the product, sell the brand and explain the new service included with the purchase.

features.title: Massive new users numbers
features.description: The campaign was a massive success within the niche of this type of products, generating more than 5000 leads in the two months that was online.

cases.name: Verizon

home.alt: Prints and gifts augmented reality app inside the Verizon cloud.

features.title: Redesign Print & Gifts app
features.description: Problems in categorization, flows and technology, made the previous experience difficult to use, and generated little to no engagement on the service.

features.title: New tech and Improvements
features.description: From improvements in flows, categorization and architecture, to interaction design and the inclusion of new augmented reality technology to differenciate from competition.

features.title: Personalized experience
features.description: Changes made possible that the users experienced a much more personalized product that responded to their needs in ways they hadn’t experienced before.

home.alt: Redefining families experience in the parks through the app.

features.title: Outdated app experience
features.description: Un-structured components, misleading actions and arquitecture, Un-focused sections and unnecessary tools for users that wanted a different experience being on-site.

features.title: Deep UX research
features.description: Redefinition of flows, architecture, red routes, mental and physical costs of interaction and setting the steps to lead a new and better experience for the primary use cases.

features.title: A new station of fun on the spot
features.description: The changes created a new way of experiencing the park before, during and after visiting the Lodges. Generating better ratings for the brand and higher revenue for parks.
